He’s writing it merely to crystallize his own thoughts. He argues in favor of free will, going against the growing orthodoxy of his time, which indicates that all human behavior is governed by circumstances and can be predicted. In opposition to this, he lives in a way contrary to society, and against his own “profit”, for the mere pleasure of being a person who decides for himself. I always liked Veitch’s work, but this series seemed more extreme than his earlier work. It was too much for me at that time, but it left me curious. A super-powered infant modeled after Superman decapitating hundreds of people. A man who gains weird powers by bathing in bat guano. (He’s actually called “El Guano” — “The Shit” — a translation caption keeps telling us).An elderly Sherlock Holmes appears, for no discernible reason, as do analogues of Jerry Seigel, Joe Shuster, Walt Disney/Harry Donenfeld, George Reeves, and Robert Oppenheimer. Somehow, a few historical figures appear without the obfuscation of a name change: Albert Einstein, David Niven, Peter Lorre.I don’t want to give anything away, but in the end, it’s a story about the idea of the superhero and how it relates to the collective psyche of the 20th century. It includes references to how the comic book business chewed up and spat out its best talent, the Manhattan Project, and the later “darkening” of superheroes in the eighties. Some references to Veitch’s previous “Brat Pack” story is in there, and may confuse readers who haven’t also read that work.It’s an interesting misch-masch of ideas, but it just doesn’t gel. The last chapter seemed to shoehorn all the ideas together in a rush that didn’t make too much sense. It seemed like a twelve issue series that unexpectedly had to be finished in the seventh issue due to sales or contractual issues. Most of the appeal of Veitch’s work is watching his brilliant mind “dream up” disturbing takes on comics, popular culture, and current events. Where those books were all action, this one is more of a detective story where Titus Crown, the Black sheriff of a backward Virginia county, hunts a serial killer. Titus keep arriving too late to stop murder after murder, until the final climactic scene. SPOILER WARNING:If you’re one of those mystery readers who tries to guess who the killer is based on the characters you’ve been introduced to (and there are many) and clues dropped, you can forget it. The culprit, although mentioned, doesn’t really appear in the story until he’s unmasked. He’s mentioned, and his name contains a clue, but that’s about it. This mystery doesn’t contain that type of guessing game.Titus Crown, though, is one of Cosby’s best characters, and Cosby does a great job at setting up the town, local personalities, and relationships. I’d like to see Titus, his father and brother, erstwhile girlfriends Darlene and Kelly, and Charon County again. I’d like to see Titus and crew star in a series.This book is more introspective and political than Cosby’s other books. Don’t get me wrong, the political soapbox isn’t one I disagree with. It’s just that, given the freight-train action of his earlier books, the weight of the politics camouflages what this book really is (and what I came here for— I ain’t lyin’): a violent crime thriller. Oh, you’ll get your violence. Until the fight at the end though, most of the violence is encountered in the grisly aftermath, rather than as it is happening. So what you have is a whodunnit (where you really can’t play the game, because the killer doesn’t come from an array of potential suspects) the introspection and politics characteristic of a literary novel, and the climax of a crime thriller. His capacity for self-criticism is both instructive and endearing. He has made substantial revisions to the earlier editions of this book in order to fine tune the precision of language.Kendi’s definitions focus on racist policies and ideas rather than racist individuals. And he sets out his thesis that these policies and ideas don’t come from hatred and ignorance, but rather that hatred and ignorance follow the policies, which are promulgated due to self-interest by groups and individuals. That the self-interest really doesn’t apply to benefit all members of the group, but only to certain privileged members, a small percentage. The rest of the members of the supposedly benefitted group are actually harmed by racist policies.Race is a construct, or a “mirage”. It has no biological basis in science. There is no “Black gene”, “White gene”, or “Asian gene”. What made him lovable, to the people that knew him, was that he got better as he aged. review: I’m a Moore-head, so obviously I snatched up this book and read it. It’s a collection of short stories including one long enough to be called a novel.I’m a Moore-head, so obviously I snatched up this book and read it. It’s a collection of short stories including one long enough to be called a novel.HYPOTHETICAL LIZARD (three stars) I read this one three decades ago when it came out in a collection of prose stories by comic book writers called Words Without Pictures. It’s a fantasy that takes place in a brothel in a mythical city, where (SPOILER WARNING) an imprisoned concubine escapes by impersonating their free lover, leaving the lover in their place. It reads like a decent Ursula K. LeGuin story from the early 70s. Or maybe something by Michael Moorcock. Not as original as most work by Moore.NOT EVEN LEGEND (four stars) A society for the investigation of the paranormal routinely investigates urban legends. One of their number suggests they start to investigate paranormal beings who have remained hidden even from becoming legendary in the form of folk tales. This prompts a pair of such creatures to infiltrate the group. An inventive story and fun to read.LOCATION, LOCATION, LOCATION (four stars) During the Revelation/Rapture/Second Coming, the resurrected Jesus meets with his attorney, who has been engaged to handle the paperwork in transferring the universe to its new owner. Again, inventive and fun.COLD READING (three stars) a fake psychic get a taste of his own medicine. Pretty good, but ultimately the kind of thing you’ve already read in an old E.C. comic.THE IMPROBABLY COMPLEX HIGH ENERGY STATE (five stars for originality, two for enjoyability). In the first femtosecond of time at the beginning of the universe, a spontaneously generated consciousness emerges, followed by another, then by a whole passel of them. The original takes charge, and tries to set itself up as the god/creator/dictator of the rest. Sometimes Moore has a clever idea, and milks it to its logical conclusion, but the result is predictable. Although the story sometimes got a chuckle out of me (Moore is often very funny), I just wanted to get on to the next story.ILLUMINATIONS (five stars) A recently divorced man decides to visit a beach resort where he remembered being happy as a child, and in so doing, discovers that nostalgia engenders disappointment, boredom, and finally, horror. I’ve never seen nostalgia dealt with so effectively as a springboard for a horror story, and this one hits all the good marks.WHAT WE CAN KNOW ABOUT THUNDERMAN (five stars) I give this 240 page novel my highest rating, but I think full enjoyment of it requires a lot of knowledge about the history of American comic books. If you do have that knowledge, you’ll recognize certain people, thinly disguised: Stan Lee, Jack Kirby, Roy Thomas, Vince Colletta, Archie Goodwin, etc. Many plot points and anecdotes are lifted from actual history. Some are made up or obfuscated. Comic pros and fans may be (delightfully) scandalized by this story. Is Moore bitter about his treatment and others’ treatment by an industry which chews up and spits out talented artists, while keeping the results of their creativity as cash cows? Definitely. That’s not to say he’s wrong. What gives the story its added frisson is the idea that American Comics (DC basically), is the earthly maw of some larger, Lovecraftian evil. Great stuff!AMERICAN LIGHT - AN APPRECIATION, BY C.F. BIRD (four stars for the poem, two stars for the story concept) Okay, so ostensibly this is a poem by an actual San Francisco writer of the beat generation, given explanatory footnotes by a critic, C.F. Bird. The poet and the critic are fictional, but the supporting cast and other geographic references are real. The poem is full of references to real Beat Generation people: Ginsberg, Kerouac, Cassady, etc., and references to ancient Egyptian mythology. The notes unironically explain the references contained in the poem. The structure of this story reminds me of Nabokov’s brilliant Pale Fire, which has a similar structure, only where the critic is insane, and perhaps a murderer, and the footnotes can be read for a suspense plot. The comparison is inevitable, and Moore’s story suffers by it. It just can’t compete at the level of Pale Fire. Good poem, though.AND, AT THE LAST, JUST TO BE DONE WITH SILENCE (three stars) This one refers to an historical event in the middle ages with which I’m unfamiliar. They hang him. and them are punished by having to dig him up out of his grave and bear him around the countryside, where they are flogged. review: This is a collection of interconnected short stories, all taking place in East Liverpool, Ohio and environs. East Liverpool was once a thriving small This is a collection of interconnected short stories, all taking place in East Liverpool, Ohio and environs. East Liverpool was once a thriving small city supported by nearby steel mills and potteries. Starting in the eighties, East Liverpool’s economy started to go downhill with the closure of the mills, and has never recovered. I grew up there. I currently live there. Karen Kotrba, in these stories, really captures the ambience of my hometown.Given the interconnectedness of the stories, and the Ohio setting, one might either expect the elegiac quality of Sherwood Anderson’s Winesburg, Ohio, or the dark, twisted Appallachian noir of Donald Ray Pollock’s Knockemstiff. But neither of those is apposite. Rather, the characters are likable schmoes muddling through life on the edge of poverty. But they’re self-aware schmoes. They understand their their position and can laugh at themselves. The stories recall those of Raymond Carver, and are truly worthy of that comparison. The dialog feels natural, and the anecdotes that provide color are funny and awkward. Images and events in the stories will settle in your mind and take up residence. I’ll say though, this book needs a better title. I remember when I was a kid, seeing the pictures of starving African children wiAn eye-opening book about the Nigeria/Biafra war of the late sixties. I remember when I was a kid, seeing the pictures of starving African children with emaciated limbs and distended bellies. We were encouraged to donate to charities, go door to door and collect money and so forth. But we were never made aware of the physical and political causes this starvation.According to this novel, colonialism had resulted in the people of Nigeria viewing each other as separate tribes, with the Muslims of the north more easily brought under the control of the English because they could pay off the local headman, while the democratic peoples of the south (later known as the Igbo people) were harder to control. Eventually the Igbo people were scapegoated as being grasping and money-hungry, and finally subjected to genocidal violence. The Igbo people centralized in the southeast, and declared themselves a new nation (Biafra), sparking a war of secession. Biafra was ultimately defeated, because the Nigerians were able to starve them out, and the rest of the world was apathetic toward Biafra. When the war ended, the Igbo people, who had been successful in business and academics, were impoverished, their property having been destroyed or confiscated. The book follows an Igbo family, principally led by twin sisters Kainene and Olanna, their significant others Richard, a white Englishman and Odenigbo, an Igbo professor, respectively. Another major character is Ugwu, Odenigbo's houseboy, a village boy who educates himself and becomes more sophisticated as the story progresses. The personal family drama of these characters is just as important as the larger story of the war. In fact, the war is only presented through the personal points of view of the characters. If you're a newbie Marvel fan who always assumed Stan Lee created everything, this book will set you straight. Kirby, not Lee, was always the creative force behind most of the comic book characters you know and love. Be prepared for Stan to come off as a villain--even as the inspiration for Loki.Writer/artist Tom Scioli, channeling Kirby, makes a credible case that Jack deserves some credit for the creation of a couple of characters he's not usually associated with: Spider-Man and Iron Man. It's hard to believe it was written in 1899.In it, a young wife and mother, while on vacation at Grand Isle, Louisiana, falls in love with a young man. Before this love is consummated or declared on either side, the young man leaves for Mexico. The young woman, Edna, goes back home to New Orleans with her husband and little sons. She is changed, awakened. She has a sense that she belongs to herself rather than to her husband, her sons, or the social strictures of New Orleans society. She begins to live for herself, pursuing art. And when her husband leaves for New York on an extended business trip, she abandons the big house and sets up a small apartment for herself. She becomes embroiled in a tentative love affair with another man.Her friend, an elderly musician, tells her: "The bird that would soar above the level plain of tradition and prejudice must have strong wings." Does Edna have strong wings? She had told another friend she would not sacrifice herself for her children. She would sacrifice all material things. Even her life. But not herself.Near the end of the book, the young man she had fallen in love with on Grand Isle comes back. A reckoning is had. The ending of the book, at first glance, could be taken as the tragic ending of a morality tale about adultery, like Madame Bovary or Anna Karenina. But something different is going on here. Edna meets a final fate, but I don't get from it that she's in despair. She's instead, taking her own life as a positive choice. Claiming her life and the disposition of it as her own. Simak, which reads like it could have been one of the better Twilight Zone episodes.As an actor, I appreciated "The Darfsteller" by Walter M. Miller, Jr., which is about an out-of-work actor who gets another chance to take the stage after actors have been replaced by machines."The Hell-Bound Train" by Robert Bloch and "Or All the Seas with Oysters" by Avram Davidson were, like Simak's story, reminiscent of The Twilight Zone. Earthbound stories rooted in the mundane, with a paranormal or science fictional twist."The Star" by Arthur C. Clarke is essentially a Christmas story. Of course, saying that might be a spoiler. The conceit of the story is that the Star of Bethlehem was a supernova that destroyed a great civilization. My problem with it was that the voyager who discovered it 1000 years in the future, 3000 light years from Earth, extrapolated that the star went nova about the time of Christ's birth, and that's why the star was extra bright. But if that were the case, it wouldn't have been visible as such on Earth until the time the story took place."Exploration Team" by Murray Leinster speculates a future where exploration of alien worlds is aided by genetically modified bears (bred to be as friendly to humans as dogs). Add a bald eagle equipped with a camera for reconnaissance and various deadly alien animals and you have the makings of a nice adventure story."The Long Voyage" by Poul Anderson, plotwise, was not very remarkable, but I really appreciated Anderson's use of a more archaic, seafaring language.My least favorite was "The Allamagoosa" by Eric Frank Russell, which is literally a shaggy dog story that ends in a sort of pun. Kind of a groaner, actually. There is an element of science fiction fandom which has always appreciated stunted humor, I guess. Overall, it's apparent that the science fiction of the time was rife with libertarian ideas. The heroes, for the most part, are "rugged individualists" who feel life if only worth living if you pull yourself up by your bootstraps and do it yourself, without the help of any government or benevolent alien race. In the story, a juvenile on trial for murder in Vermont is told she would be tried as an adult and would have to go to prison "in Oklahoma". What? The murder would have been a state offense, not federal, and therefore, if convicted, she would have served time in a Vermont prison.I think sometimes people don't realize that each state has its own penal system for crimes committed therein. Or somehow they confuse "state" and "federal" with "misdemeanor" and "felony", as if the more serious crimes are federal crimes and the less serious ones are state crimes. No. That's not how it works.Anyway, aside from this little jarring (to me) episode, it was a good read....more

I'll say this right out front--the characters aren't realistically drawn. They're larger-than-life heroes. Or villains. Or sidekicks. Or mysterious beings. But that's not why you come to a book like this.You come to be transported to a different world. Strange races. Different societies with different codes of conduct. Weird plant and animal life. Forgotten lore. Historical mysteries. Magic powers. Bloody combat. You'll find all of that, along with mysteries: some that are revealed, only to have other mysteries lurking behind them. The magic, with its built-in limits of drawing and using power, seems believable.I had read about halfway through Sanderson's Mistborn trilogy and was bothered by the fact that a withered, sick land without agriculture was still able to sustain a rather large population. In this book, I don't have that quibble. The weird ecosystem feels like it could exist.I hope the subsequent volumes excite me as much. So far, I'm really enjoying the ride.Edit: I'm almost finished with the second volume, Words of Radiance, and I'm going to take back what I said about the characters not being realistically drawn.
